reviews.text: If you want more laughs than you shouldn’t miss The Hangover Part II, just don’t expect anything remarkably different this time around… in fact to be safe just check your brain in at the Candy Bar on your way in.
reviews.author: David Griffiths

reviews.text: Even if The Hangover Part II is, in essence, a predictable mirror image of the first film, just in a new setting, doesn't make it any less funny or entertainingly over-the-top.
reviews.author: Don Shanahan

reviews.text: The shock-based laughs were forgivable with The Hangover given the novelty of the concept, but there’s no pardoning the do-over feel of this sequel.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: It wasn't that bad and we laughed a lot.
reviews.author: Julie and Brandy

reviews.text: Offers another dose of debauched misadventures from the "wolf pack" of comedians, sure to please those hungering for more after the original film.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: For the most part, director Todd Phillips plays it safe and goes for the surefire box-office hit.
reviews.author: Richard Propes

reviews.text: An almost identical rehash of the first film.
reviews.author: Brent McKnight

reviews.text: This is a movie of bad things happening to relatively bad people, with precious little humor to break up the ugliness.
reviews.author: Sean Collier

reviews.text: A reprehensible film that is completely devoid of laughs.
reviews.author: David Harris

reviews.text: The Hangover Part II answers this riddle: how can a movie be a doting copy of the original and have the opposite effect?
reviews.author: Brian D. Johnson

reviews.text: It's a fun distracting mile a minute race to the ridiculous last scene. That's what the title promises, and that's what you get.
reviews.author: Leslie Combemale

reviews.text: I'll admit it is fun to see these familiar characters again, even if it feels like we've seen this before. Cooper seems so relaxed as Phil that I think it is easy to overlook how good he really is here, while Helms isn't afraid to be the butt of the joke.
reviews.author: Micheal Compton

reviews.text: If you want to see everything you saw in Hangover, only transplanted to Bangkok, with a drug-peddling simian and a missing human finger, then Hangover 2 is the movie for you.
reviews.author: Shubhra Gupta

reviews.text: There are plenty of laughs to be had from the outrageous situations in which the guys find themselves.
reviews.author: Kelly Jane Torrance

reviews.text: A sluggish, pointless and overly vulgar shot for shot copy of its far superior forebearer, though it is neither as clever or as tactful.
reviews.author: Edward Frost

reviews.text: An obnoxious installment in an obnoxious franchise, The Hangover Part II is also (intentionally or not) fascinatingly bent on disconcerting its target audience.
reviews.author: Fernando F. Croce

reviews.text: The wickedly entertaining characters and actors each leave audiences in stitches as they go through the motions of an equally entertaining--albeit redone--plot that will thrill die-hard fans of the original.
reviews.author: Candice Frederick

reviews.text: I don't believe that these characters would ever be friends, I don't like spending time with them, and I do not care what happens to them or their weddings or their adoptive babies or their relationship with Mike Tyson.
reviews.author: Lindy West

reviews.text: Raunchy and unfunny, this sequel feels like a simple retread of its predecessor.
reviews.author: John Hanlon

reviews.text: If you love the first film, seriously, do not see this one. You'll ruin two movies at once.
reviews.author: Will Leitch

reviews.text: The cast is once again at the top of their game and there are some genuinely hilarious moments, but on the whole, The Hangover Part II is way too similar to the first film to be enjoyable.
reviews.author: Matt Joseph

reviews.text: The Hangover: Part II shows the writers have absolutely no faith in their characters or their own ability to take them somewhere new.
reviews.author: Ali Gray

reviews.text: Overall, your enjoyment of this film will correlate directly to your enjoyment of the previous film. If you liked it, you'll like this one, if not, you won't enjoy the sequel as it's just more of the same.
reviews.author: Jeff Beck

reviews.text: I think the first one is like GONE WITH THE WIND compared to this tired old turd.
reviews.author: Austin Kennedy

reviews.text: Visually dazzling, well shot and perhaps richer in character than the first film -- but also nowhere near as clever, refreshing or funny.
reviews.author: R.L. Shaffer

reviews.text: It is the epitome of lazy Hollywood filmmaking.
reviews.author: Greg Maki

reviews.text: There are one or two good jokes and the cast is mainly likeable but the rest of the material is so predictable and tawdry that the entire film becomes something of a chore
reviews.author: Laurence Boyce

reviews.text: ...almost the same gang of dimwits are up to the same shenanigans, with Thailand substituting for Vegas.
reviews.author: John J. Puccio

reviews.text: The guys are just as clueless after a wild night on the town, but getting lost amid the goggle-bright lights of Las Vegas seems like a fairground ride compared to Bangkok.
reviews.author: Stella Papamichael

reviews.text: One drink too many, The Hangover Part II relies too much on its talented cast and not enough on the laughs.
reviews.author: Rory Meyer

reviews.text: This is not a case of imitation being the sincerest form of flattery-it is indolent narcissism of the most nauseating kind.
reviews.author: Brandon Fibbs

reviews.text: More a horror than a comedic film, as if Todd Phillips is making a kind of "Heart of Darkness" argument with Bangkok as his backdrop.
reviews.author: Stephen Himes

reviews.text: If you can look past the fact that this film is closer to a remake than a sequel, it's an enjoyable way to spend an hour and a half. Might not be original, but it's still funny.
reviews.author: Andreas Heinemann

reviews.text: ...as needless a contemporary sequel as one can easily recall...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: It might not be quite as much fun as the first film but it's fun enough - and that's all that counts. Plus, there's a monkey in it.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: "It happened again." That's the opening gambit of The Hangover: Part II, but sadly the same can be said of the franchise.
reviews.author: Sam Bathe

reviews.text: If you liked The Hangover, you're going to like The Hangover Part II because it is the same movie.
reviews.author: James Verniere

reviews.text: Hangover 2 far too Familiar
reviews.author: Charles Koplinski

reviews.text: Unless moviegoers themselves are willing to shoulder some of the blame, it's useless to try and figure out why The Hangover Part II is so bad. The film only exists because, after the hilarious 2009 movie broke box-office records for an R-rated comedy...
reviews.author: Leonard Maltin

reviews.text: For me, the bottom line is, did I laugh? And I did. As much as I did the first time around.
reviews.author: David Poland

reviews.text: This may be the one time in recorded history where a second hangover is a good thing. Bartender, serve up another round with the wolf pack.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Lyles

reviews.text: If its hugely successful 2009 predecessor served up a lot of raucous laughs and guilt-free entertainment, this seems intent on dishing out morning- after-style punishment for all the fun that was had.
reviews.author: Alistair Harkness

reviews.text: Missing is the deliriously unpredictable inventiveness of the first film, replaced by variations on its most memorable bits.
reviews.author: Siobhan Synnot

reviews.text: The reason [the first one] worked so well was because of the unique concept and the mystery structure. Now the concept is familiar and the mystery isn't engaging. [This is} the very definition of a lazy, pointless sequel.
reviews.author: Eric Melin

reviews.text: Seamlessly applies the Hangover structure to a new setting. The beauty of it is it could happen anywhere, or with anyone (i.e. franchise.)
reviews.author: Fred Topel

reviews.text: As this is the boys' fate, it speaks also to assumptions about viewers, that they're satisfied with a wheel that takes them nowhere surprising, repeating a semblance of plot points and a series of gags.
reviews.author: Cynthia Fuchs

reviews.text: If you laughed your butt off in the first film, you'll laugh half your butt off here, and even that is generally worth the price of admission these days.
reviews.author: Burl Burlingame

reviews.text: Phillips and company are treading water, going through the motions in order to pick up a quick paycheck before moving onto something else.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: You know, this isn't all that original. Even for a sequel, it's unashamedly derivative. But I kept thinking, as I gasped, sometimes with laughter and sometimes from shock, that 'The Hangover Part II' still is hilarious more often than it's not.
reviews.author: Linda Cook

reviews.text: It feels less like The Hangover Part II than it does like The Hangover 2.0, as if Phillips were trying to go back and make the first film funnier instead of making a new one.
reviews.author: Joshua Starnes

reviews.text: The Hangover Part II isn't a dud, exactly -- some of it is very funny, and there are a few memorable jolts and outlandish dirty moments. But it feels, at times, like a routine adventure film set overseas.
reviews.author: David Denby

reviews.text: More mean spirited than fun.
reviews.author: John Wirt

reviews.text: Stu, Phil, and Alan are like the Three Stooges: the backdrop may look a little different, but it's the same ladder to the gut and poke in the eye again.
reviews.author: MaryAnn Johanson

reviews.text: Man, did they blow it with this one.
reviews.author: Bob Grimm

reviews.text: Five credited writers have made the sequel darker, much less funny and provided the type of bad behavior in another country that pretty much defines the term "ugly Americans."
reviews.author: Lori Hoffman

reviews.text: The makers of The Hangover Part II have pulled off one of the most blatantly lazy acts of filmmaking in recent memory. And it still works.
reviews.author: Tim Martain

reviews.text: little more than a repetitive, desperate sequel, the very definition of unnecessary
reviews.author: James Kendrick

reviews.text: What was dumb in the original is dumber in the sequel; what was crude in the original is cruder in the sequel; Galiafinakis was obnoxious in the original and he is more so in the sequel.
reviews.author: Jackie K. Cooper

reviews.text: Director Todd Phillips Should be Given Credit for Making a Darker, Edgier Film But A Lot of the Shock is Lost with Predictable Material.
reviews.author: Jimmy O

reviews.text: What's missing is a huge part of what made the first film so good: the element of surprise.
reviews.author: Stephen Silver

reviews.text: Funnier than the first one, for what that's worth.
reviews.author: Kelly Vance

reviews.text: I didn't laugh a whole lot at this grimier, darker sequel, but I found it consistently more interesting, visually and thematically, than the first.
reviews.author: Rob Gonsalves

reviews.text: It's a dark and morbid cash-in and nothing more...
reviews.author: Felix Vasquez Jr.

reviews.text: It's fun to hang out with these guys again ... until it isn't. The problems with the first film seem amplified in the second.
reviews.author: Jeff Bayer

reviews.text: By definition, a sequel is just more of the same. In the case of The Hangover Part II, that's a very welcome redundancy indeed
reviews.author: Christopher Null

reviews.text: Sure, it's a rehash of the first movie's plot, but it's still funny. Just not as funny as the original.
reviews.author: Scott Nash

reviews.text: Same deal as the original.
reviews.author: Dennis Schwartz

reviews.text: The Hangover Part II sees the same ingredients shaken up in the kaleidoscope, but a less attractive and far less amusing pattern emerges.
reviews.author: Philip French

reviews.text: "The Hangover Part II" is what you will expect. I don't think it was better then the first but it did a great job at being just as good.
reviews.author: Jolene Mendez

reviews.text: Those yearning for some summertime bawdiness at the movies would be well-advised to check out Bridesmaids instead, as any random scene in that picture is better than anything on display in The Hangover Part II.
reviews.author: Matt Brunson

reviews.text: This film is more fun than it has any business being.
reviews.author: Widgett Walls

reviews.text: Laff-out-loud raunchy ... delivers on its promise to not leave one sacred cow standing, one nationality or sexual designation unsullied. How many films can make that claim?
reviews.author: Glenn Lovell

reviews.text: The movie exceeds expectations! The acters carve out a special comedy niche that will not be easily forgotten. They operate like a well-oiled machine with perfect comedic timing and a contagious form of winning camaraderie. The clever lines of...
reviews.author: Keith Cohen

reviews.text: It's all very close to being offensive, but as the joke's on the Americans, the film gets away with it.
reviews.author: Jason Di Rosso

reviews.text: a lazy excrescence
reviews.author: Andrea Chase

reviews.text: Adheres to the old maxim "if it ain't broke, don't fix it," yet somehow manages to break it while not fixing it.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: The things that worked best about the first movie still work... while the things that were worst have become even more grating.
reviews.author: Tim Brayton

reviews.text: Is it as brilliant as No. 1? No. How could it be? But Hangover Deux still provides lots of fun laughs, and there's more Zach Galifianakis' twisted Alan. This is good.
reviews.author: Clint O'Connor

reviews.text: You could literally smash yourself in the face with a frying pan, stumble into this movie and mistake it for the original... almost.
reviews.author: Kevin Carr

reviews.text: It's really pretty simple: If you laughed at the first "The Hangover," you will most assuredly laugh at "The Hangover Part II."
reviews.author: Mathew DeKinder

reviews.text: It just might be the worst sequel ever to a really good movie.
reviews.author: Michael Smith

reviews.text: Are we really so immature and/or penis-averse we have to shriek like middle schoolers every time one...pops up?
reviews.author: Pete Vonder Haar

reviews.text: Think of it as a decent high school football player who suffers from having an older brother who was all-state two years earlier.
reviews.author: Ben Mankiewicz

reviews.text: At least it's not in 3D.
reviews.author: Rob Vaux

reviews.text: The Hangover Part II feels like the fifth or sixth installment in the franchise. It's that out of fresh ideas.
reviews.author: Christian Toto

reviews.text: I am not going to deny The Hangover Part II follows the same blueprint as the first film, but, to be honest, it didn't bother me one bit. The reason? I was too busy laughing to care.
reviews.author: Adam Tobias

reviews.text: The missing person, the seamy urban setting, the gradual accretion of clues: The Hangover films are, essentially, hard-boiled crime stories spun into comic depravity.
reviews.author: Christopher Orr

reviews.text: Maybe every wild party boy has a deep-seeded inner queer.
reviews.author: Rob Humanick

reviews.text: ...director Todd Phillips wrongly seems to think he can solve any problem with more mayhem. How about better jokes instead?
reviews.author: Corey Hall

reviews.text: It delivers what you'd expect from the team that brought you the first film but nothing new... unless you think a monkey smoking and Thai trannies are something new and exciting.
reviews.author: Beth Accomando

reviews.text: The Hangover Part II falls into the greatest trap of the comedy sequel: assuming the audience wants the exact same thing, but even more so.
reviews.author: Matthew Razak

reviews.text: There are plenty of déjà vu moments,...but before you know it, Phillips yanks you in an entirely unexpected direction, continually ramping up the stakes, the raunch and the visceral humor.
reviews.author: Alison Gang

reviews.text: One could easily mistake this supposed blockbuster for a mockbuster. After all, it was co-written by one of the scribblers of the Scary Movie series.
reviews.author: Anders Wotzke

reviews.text: ...makes an excellent companion piece to the original...
reviews.author: Bill Gibron

reviews.text: To paraphrase statements from the characters: we've done it again doesn't do it again.
reviews.author: Gary Wolcott

reviews.text: About halfway through, Galifianakis wails, "I just wanted things to say the same!" If Warner Brothers were being completely honest, that'd be 'The Hangover Part II''s ad line.
reviews.author: Jason Bailey

reviews.text: I can't dismiss the ugliness behind many of its antics.
reviews.author: Peter Rainer

reviews.text: It's the same movie, just with different details plopped in place of the previous ones.
reviews.author: Grae Drake

reviews.text: Director Phillips whips along proceedings at break-neck speed, perhaps in the hope that we won't notice how all the quirks we loved the first time are nothing like as funny the second time
reviews.author: Anthony Quinn

reviews.text: I laughed all the way through it, just like I laughed all the way through the first one.
reviews.author: Dave White

reviews.text: The terrific idea behind the first one -- a mystery story based around a night of total debauchery -- has no more shock.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: The Hangover Part II gets considerable mileage out of following precisely the same structure as the first film.
reviews.author: Norman Wilner

reviews.text: How much you'll go for it depends on whether, like our beleaguered comrades, you partake in a tipple before seeing it...
reviews.author: Shaun Munro

reviews.text: I can't believe how precisely everything does happen again, except that what was fresh and surprising in Las Vegas turns rancid and predictable in Bangkok, where yet another wedding is scheduled to take place.
reviews.author: Joe Morgenstern

reviews.text: It's not with a sense of delight that you realise you're on exactly the same ride again but with dawning dismay.
reviews.author: Derek Malcolm

reviews.text: The more rational characters have lost any redeeming qualities and this makes the film hard to watch - for all the wrong reasons.
reviews.author: Alex Zane

reviews.text: Best watched drunk - that way you might awake with no memory of the experience.
reviews.author: David Edwards

reviews.text: A tasteless, preposterous and ultimately pointless tale of east meets west which lurches from one improbable set piece to the next including the bizarre concealment of a dead body and a high-speed car chase.
reviews.author: Catherine Jones

reviews.text: Every time a character in this follow-up groans "I can't believe this is happening again", you can only nod forlornly in agreement.
reviews.author: Matt Neal

reviews.text: Business and creative people go together as well as fine wine at a burger joint. For this sequel, the brass beat out the artists and afford us the double-edged sword of the same exact formula from two years ago.
reviews.author: Adam Fendelman

reviews.text: [VIDEO] The formula mold that worked so well the first time around loses some steam in this follow up to the most successful R-rated movie
reviews.author: Cole Smithey

reviews.text: Despite a few slow patches, it is loaded with gut-busting laughs. After its much brainier predecessor, though, it feels like a well-meaning kid forced to follow in the footsteps of his genius older sibling.
reviews.author: Christopher Lloyd

reviews.text: There are a lot of things to dislike about this derivative sequel, but at the top of the list is its appalling vulgarity, which crossed the line the first avoided.
reviews.author: Tony Medley

reviews.text: Directed, like the wildly successful first film, by Todd Phillips, it airlifts the original characters, premise, and story structure out of Vegas and plonks them down in Bangkok in near-identical form, save for a few instances of ante-upping.
reviews.author: Dana Stevens

reviews.text: It's a tribute to the filmmakers, particularly director and co-writer Todd Phillips, that the best way to approach The Hangover Part II is to talk about what it isn't. It isn't a typical sequel, either a watered-down encore or a muddled [extension].
reviews.author: Tom Maurstad

reviews.text: The Hangover Part II is the worst sequel of all time.
reviews.author: Christopher Tookey

reviews.text: Whereas The Hangover was borderline outrageous as it stacked one mesmerizing vulgarity atop the next, this second exercise in bad manners (presumably of four) feels rote in comparison.
reviews.author: Marc Savlov

reviews.text: Those who enjoyed The Hangover for its gross out insanity will appreciate this film, and it is possessed of a stronger ending than its predecessor, however anyone looking for novelty or a fresh take will be disappointed.
reviews.author: Giles Hardie

reviews.text: The premise and the execution are numbingly familiar, and what was funny and unexpected about a guys-bonding-under-pressure movie the first time around becomes: ''Are they kidding? Again?''
reviews.author: Philippa Hawker

reviews.text: It's not that "Hangover II" is a notably bad movie. It's more that nothing in it seems to justify all the effort spent to add a new but nearly identical series of episodes to the original.
reviews.author: Shawn Levy

reviews.text: The Hangover Part II is, for the most part, an exceedingly hacky comedy.
reviews.author: Alonso Duralde

reviews.text: This buzz-kill follow-up suffers from a pervasive sense of been there, drunk that.
reviews.author: Matt Stevens

reviews.text: Such is the genius of the original movie, it still feels fresh in carbon copy form with some more end credits guaranteed to have anyone who has just popped a boiled sweet in danger of laughing themselves to death.
reviews.author: Graham Young

reviews.text: Shifts to Bangkok for a few laughs and a whole lot of desperation.
reviews.author: Robert Denerstein

reviews.text: May be a rehash, but it's a funny rehash.
reviews.author: Chris Bumbray

reviews.text: One of the most uninspired and unoriginal sequels you'll ever see. Or not see, if you're lucky.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: Phillips and his co-writers, Craig Mazin and Scot Armstrong, seem to have launched into this project with a misguided faith in their own brilliance, but nothing resembling an idea or a story.
reviews.author: Andrew O'Hehir

reviews.text: The filmmakers can't recapture the original's novelty or freshness, so they up the raunch level considerably; the matter-of-factness of the transsexual and gay-panic jokes is almost progressive.
reviews.author: Nathan Rabin

reviews.text: If The Hangover gave you hope for Hollywood - yup, there is some creativity and boldness left - The Hangover Part II sinks it.
reviews.author: Henry Fitzherbert

reviews.text: Raunchy comedy sequel is cruder, less funny, than original.
reviews.author: S. Jhoanna Robledo

reviews.text: The Hangover made the actors A-list Hollywood stars. But despite the indisputable talent of this cast, The Hangover Part II doesn't deliver the same zany punch of its predecessor.
reviews.author: Gayle MacDonald

reviews.text: Pushing the envelope farther and making this more crass didn't increase the funny.
reviews.author: Vic Holtreman

reviews.text: As much as the original "Hangover" was fresh and funny, "The Hangover Part II" is just stale and painful.
reviews.author: David Kaplan

reviews.text: Maybe what goes on in Vegas really should stay in Vegas.
reviews.author: Tom Long

reviews.text: Alas, this time there are about three or four mild laughs in the whole picture, and the entire visual aspect of the movie is a botched disappointment.
reviews.author: Mick LaSalle

reviews.text: It follows the same essential pattern as its predecessor, but the ingenious loopiness is gone; the mechanism behind it grinds instead of whirrs.
reviews.author: Stephanie Zacharek

reviews.text: This is a faded copy of its predecessor, only raunchier (if you can imagine) and with better scenery.
reviews.author: Loey Lockerby

reviews.text: Somebody must have roofied me. I left The Hangover Part II feeling dazed and abused, wondering how bad things happened to such a good comedy.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: Sluggish, erratic attempt to duplicate the first, better movie.
reviews.author: Rich Heldenfels

reviews.text: "The Hangover Part II" is such a complete copy of the original 2009 hit comedy that I'd be surprised if the writers even bothered to create a new Microsoft Word file when they wrote it.
reviews.author: Rob Thomas

reviews.text: If there's such thing as plagiarizing your own work, Hangover Part II is the best example. Also, for those folks who drink to get plastered, fist pump at the club, splurge on a hooker and say racial epithets for fun - you've finally found your franchise!
reviews.author: Clay Cane

reviews.text: We all enjoyed ourselves during that first movie. But now ... well, the hangover has begun.
reviews.author: Peter Bradshaw

reviews.text: According to Phillips, the 'Part II' in the title is a nod to the second Godfather, which matched the genius of its forerunner. Ironically, his own sequel offer is one you should refuse.
reviews.author: Nick De Semlyen

reviews.text: Loud, dumb, occasionally obnoxious but truly, unashamedly hilarious.
reviews.author: Matt Bochenski

reviews.text: Oh, what a headache-inducing, unapologetic money grab we have in "The Hangover Part II."
reviews.author: Betsy Sharkey

reviews.text: Stu, Alan and Phil are likely to remain America's favorite penitents, and there's still some (though not as much) humor in their pain.
reviews.author: Gary Thompson

reviews.text: It might not be great or legendary, but you are going to laugh.
reviews.author: Willie Waffle

reviews.text: If director Todd Phillips used the first movie to see how far he could push the envelope, this one licks and seals it.
reviews.author: Steve Persall

reviews.text: Painfully unfunny sequel that desperately tries to recapture the magic formula of the original film with increasingly tedious results.
reviews.author: Matthew Turner

reviews.text: Film-makers Todd Phillips and co make no apologies for being creatures of habit and sticking to what worked for them before.
reviews.author: Lisa Giles-Keddie

reviews.text: Part II has too many over-the-top moments that pull back the curtain and remind viewers that nothing we're seeing could ever really happen. What's left are some big laughs but little genuine pathos.
reviews.author: Jonathan W. Hickman

reviews.text: Tasteless, pointless, tactless and pretty much anything else you care to stick the '-less' suffix on.
reviews.author: Charlie Lyne

reviews.text: Darker and more desperate than the previous go-round, this one might have done better just to sleep it off.
reviews.author: Peter Keough

reviews.text: While these characters were amusing the first time around, Phillips and his screenwriters don't bring much new to the party.
reviews.author: Carrie Rickey

reviews.text: Less a hangover and more a mild irritation.
reviews.author: Tim Evans

reviews.text: For all the talent Hangover II reassembles, our boys just can't muster the hair of the dog that bit them the first time around.
reviews.author: Scott Bowles

reviews.text: Proving that 2009's The Hangover was a fluke, this sequel returns to filmmaker Todd Phillips' more usual mean-spirited style
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: The guys could make 12 more of these movies, do just as well every time and get audiences to laugh and laugh at themselves for laughing. That's a lot of laughing, and that's The Hangover: Part II.
reviews.author: Phil Villarreal

reviews.text: Although the production went all the way to Thailand, the comedy never ventures far from what worked in Vegas.
reviews.author: Rebecca Murray

reviews.text: It falls into the classic trap for sequels made primarily to cash in on the unexpected success of a movie: tell the same story again, only louder.
reviews.author: Daniel M. Kimmel

reviews.text: It's dumb, yeah, and hugely indefensible, but The Hangover Part II's also a specific vision of bliss.
reviews.author: Walter Chaw

reviews.text: Phillips has no sense of comic energy, relying instead on the actors ratcheting up their characters' hateful traits to 11.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: ...on the whole the movie is depressing. That's right, a big studio R-rated summer comedy followup to the biggest R-rated comedy of all time is depressing.
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: Whereas the original had the wonderful epiphany of watching a comedy that actually didn't suck, The Hangover Part II sticks strictly to its own formula - and to a fault.
reviews.author: Bill Clark

reviews.text: The Hangover Part II revels in its wickedness, and encourages viewers to do so as well. It's kind of infectious. Just because you like it, doesn't mean you have to feel good about it.
reviews.author: Simon Miraudo

reviews.text: The Hangover Part II isn't nearly as fresh or as funny as the original, [but] it still gets plenty of good mileage out of what is essentially the exact same joke.
reviews.author: Jason Zingale

reviews.text: If you want to avoid plot spoilers for The Hangover Part II, don't watch The Hangover.
reviews.author: Eric D. Snider

reviews.text: The result is a cinematic illustration of the law of diminishing returns, in which more money, more exotic locales, more crazy situations and more Mike Tyson all fuel a familiar carnival of abasement.
reviews.author: Ian Buckwalter

reviews.text: Phillips seems to be relying all too heavily on the idea that we just want to see the first movie again. (We can do that. At home. For a lot less money.)
reviews.author: Moira MacDonald

reviews.text: The action is fast, the gags are plentiful - and many actually are funny if you check your squeamishness at the door.
reviews.author: Sue Pierman

reviews.text: Using the original as a template, The Hangover Part II colors within the lines, but does so with bright fluorescents rather than drab primaries.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: We don't know what's more bizarre: Phillips' sensibility, or how he avoided an NC-17. We profit (mostly) unscathed.
reviews.author: Matthew Sorrento

reviews.text: If the first film was "The Godfather" of comedies I'd have to call this once "The Godfather Part II."
reviews.author: Michael A. Smith

reviews.text: The movie's an unclean thing and a mostly unfunny one.
reviews.author: Ty Burr

reviews.text: Less a sequel than a remake, The Hangover Part II brings the wedding smashers to Bangkok with more outrageousness but diminishing returns. Still, initial grosses will be explosive.
reviews.author: Kevin Lally

reviews.text: Not rotten - just not fresh - following its own raunchy, shenanigan-filled formula.
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: Sure, it has some scattered big are-you-kidding? laughs, but could they have at least pretended that they weren't making the exact same movie?
reviews.author: Matt Soergel

reviews.text: Bangkok may be bigger, sexier, sleazier than Vegas, but this sequel feels tired and cautious. Ed Helms does everything he can to make a not very funny film work.
reviews.author: Caryn James

reviews.text: There's no simply no way to connect with this film on a story basis.
reviews.author: Jordan Hoffman

reviews.text: Copies the original so slavishly that it's the equivalent of a big-screen rerun.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: If you superimposed a diagram that mapped out all the narrative beats, characters and jokes in "The Hangover Part II" over one for "The Hangover," the two would align almost perfectly.
reviews.author: Manohla Dargis

reviews.text: The Hangover Part II never makes a convincing argument for its existence, but it works exactly as much as it has to in order to not be a bad movie.
reviews.author: Devin Faraci

reviews.text: Part II is everything the first movie was, and less. It's crucially missing laughs and intelligence.
reviews.author: Peter Howell

reviews.text: The sequel turns not dark but revoltingly cruel.
reviews.author: Lawrence Toppman

reviews.text: It would be nice if Phillips could find something original to say when we all get together to tear the next town apart.
reviews.author: Elizabeth Weitzman

reviews.text: The Hangover Part II is what the label says: another day in which you sit there with blurred vision and a headache wondering how you came to be in the same room as several dozen other people debauched by Hollywood.
reviews.author: Nigel Andrews

reviews.text: A severe bout of sequelitis afflicts this eagerly awaited but only sporadically amusing follow-up, which changes the locale from Las Vegas to Bangkok, but keeps the formula intact.
reviews.author: Rene Rodriguez

reviews.text: It's no fun to report that this one is so perfunctory, so deeply routine even as it struggles to feel unhinged.
reviews.author: Drew McWeeny

reviews.text: I need jokes. Something more than a situation recycling the situation in the first one. I'd like filmmakers who, worldwide grosses aside, show more of an interest in filming visual comedy -- gross-out, violent, action-based, whatever -- with some finesse.
reviews.author: Michael Phillips

reviews.text: It's still fun to watch, but the first one was better.
reviews.author: J. R. Jones

reviews.text: Mistaking meanness for edge, borderline racism for irreverence and disregard for women as 'boys will be boys' solidarity, this 'Part II' is as horrifying as a 'Saw' sequel, but with fewer laughs.
reviews.author: John Beifuss

reviews.text: Most of the laughs go down easily. Most.
reviews.author: Mary F. Pols

reviews.text: A veritable textbook case of what not to do when re-making a comedy that depended on sheer surprise for most of its appeal.
reviews.author: Ann Hornaday

reviews.text: Telling a bad joke twice doesn't mean it was any good the first time.
reviews.author: Armond White

reviews.text: If you enjoyed the first one, I bet you'll enjoy this one. But a little less.
reviews.author: Chris Hewitt

reviews.text: Despite all the similarities, despite the same madcap plotting and hysterically unhinged comic filth, The Hangover Part II veers into much darker territory.
reviews.author: Amy Biancolli

reviews.text: The Hangover Part 2 definitely has its moments and a few big laughs throughout, but the most memorable thing about this second substance-induced amnesia comedy is how ultimately forgettable it is.
reviews.author: Jim Vejvoda

reviews.text: Though it hews to the template of the original, director Todd Phillips has one strategy to fall back on: Upping the ante.
reviews.author: Kevin Williamson

reviews.text: Just laziness with an active passport, employing an exotic locale to cover the moldy odor of a rehash. There are laughs to be had, but one must suffer through a disheartening display of déjà vu to find them.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: As to whether the whole thing works, yes and no. Galifianakis, I think, has definitely overextended his repertoire, but Cooper and Helms still engage, mainly because they are so good at sustaining their hysteria. Cooper is especially consistent.
reviews.author: Sandra Hall

reviews.text: What can be believed as reliable word-of-mouth is that The Hangover Part II will not leave fans with a sore head or a sorry frame of mind.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: A colossal disappointment, The term dialed-in should be replaced with The Hangover 2.
reviews.author: Julian Roman

reviews.text: We've been on this bender before, and no matter how raunchy and un-PC The Hangover Part II is, there's no disguising that this is just warmed-up leftovers that will leave a nasty taste in your mouth.
reviews.author: Randy Myers

reviews.text: The spirit is meaner, and the tone is much darker -- both of which zap the vibe of what made the original film so much fun in the first place.
reviews.author: Scott A. Mantz

reviews.text: Wastrels think the formula for a hangover is the hair of the dog, but this flaccid follow-up to the hit comedy expects us to swallow the entire rotting carcass.
reviews.author: Joe Williams

reviews.text: This isn't even really a sequel to the hilarious 2009 comedy smash set in Las Vegas. It's virtually the same movie, just transferred to another continent and with the raunch wildly amped up.
reviews.author: Randy Cordova

reviews.text: Now that we know them, the core characters are all the funnier; they've become an American suburban version of the Three Stooges.
reviews.author: Owen Gleiberman

reviews.text: Trade out Las Vegas for Bangkok, a tiger for a monkey, a lactating hooker for a trannie stripper, a missing tooth for a face tattoo, and you've got Todd Phillips's rote, dispiriting replica of his own surprise smash hit.
reviews.author: Eric Hynes

reviews.text: The laughs may be fewer and the gasps more "ewww" than "wow," but there is still some pleasure in seeing those guys suffer.
reviews.author: Nell Minow

reviews.text: As the film goes on its dull, dim-brained, slapdash way, there isn't a solitary laugh in sight. Not one. A person couldn't write worse jokes if he or she tried.
reviews.author: Dustin Putman

reviews.text: You already paid for and saw this film two years ago. Though, the version you saw then was a thousand times better. Beyond disappointing!
reviews.author: Kevin McCarthy

reviews.text: The equivalent of a drunk college student waking up the morning their book report is due and desperately trying to remember what they saw in the crappy movie version.
reviews.author: Erik Childress

reviews.text: ...[it] sacrifices plausibility, believability and empathy with anything that doesn't validate its lead characters' 'Wolf Pack' mentality in the service of a smirkingly cynical attitude.
reviews.author: Glenn Kenny

reviews.text: Every time Phillips pushed his undoubtedly formulaic sequel down yet another squalid alley for the sake of a shocking joke, I grew to appreciate, respect and even love "The Hangover Part II."
reviews.author: Sean O'Connell

reviews.text: Well, it's not as good as the original movie. It is darker and harsher in tone and the comedy is more cruel. It's also cruder.
reviews.author: Marc Lee

reviews.text: It tries to tell the same story again, with slight variations and bigger, louder, raunchier jokes and action. More, as it often does, turns out to be less.
reviews.author: Marshall Fine

reviews.text: Todd Phillips directs with increased confidence, but in every respect, The Hangover Part II is a cowardly cash-in, devoid of novelty or daring.
reviews.author: Nick Schager

reviews.text: It's amazing how fast a fresh comedy idea can go stale.
reviews.author: Geoff Berkshire

reviews.text: The unexpectedly wonderful thing about this sequel is that it actually improves on the jokes.
reviews.author: Joshua Rothkopf

reviews.text: Stranger, funnier. This is male bonding through f'd-up adversity, compared to what previously felt like acquaintances drunkenly coming to terms with their own simmering anger.
reviews.author: Matt Pais

reviews.text: Your head hurts like hell, the whole thing feels horribly familiar, and it's just not funny any more. Can this really be happening again?
reviews.author: Nigel Floyd

reviews.text: I have the sad duty to report I found this more elaborate, play-it-safe sequel far less fresh or funny.
reviews.author: Lou Lumenick

reviews.text: The MPAA's elaboration of the film's R rating says the movie has "pervasive language, strong sexual content including graphic nudity, drug use and brief violent images." Also other stuff. Maybe their space was limited.
reviews.author: Roger Ebert

reviews.text: Can't justify essentially reenacting, beat for beat, the plot of its predecessor.
reviews.author: Josh Bell

reviews.text: So closely mirrors its blockbuster predecessor in every vital aspect that it can scarcely claim the right to call itself a sequel.
reviews.author: Thomas Leupp

reviews.text: A soulless and badly unfunny retread of everything that worked the first time.
reviews.author: Katey Rich

reviews.text: The actors are having a great time with unfunny, repetitious dialogue.
reviews.author: Harvey S. Karten

reviews.text: Essentially, it's Ocean's 12 ... if a monkey stole the movie.
reviews.author: Edward Douglas

reviews.text: A huge disappointment. Not funny.
reviews.author: Victoria Alexander

reviews.text: In this world of give-'em-what-they-want, the team behind the 2009 comedy hit has reconvened to try and do just that. Too bad it doesn't work.
reviews.author: Joanna Langfield

reviews.text: Just like the memory of the wolf pack's big night out in Thailand, funny jokes seemed to have simply slipped the filmmakers' minds.
reviews.author: Perri Nemiroff

reviews.text: While not quite in the league of, say, The Empire Strikes Back or the film that it amusingly references with its title, The Godfather Part II, The Hangover Part II really is a sequel to savour... right to the bottom of the bottle.
reviews.author: Erin Free

reviews.text: The Hangover: Part II feels more like a Bangkok tourism project pitched at rapey frat boys.
reviews.author: Paul Verhoeven

reviews.text: A film that seems to have been written mainly with the find and replace function on Microsoft Word.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: The sequel has some mildly amusing moments, but it has a slapdash quality to it, and at 102 minutes, it feels padded.
reviews.author: Emanuel Levy

reviews.text: Triggers fewer belly laughs-per-minute than the original, yet nevertheless generates more than enough yucks to satisfy fans of the gross-out genre.
reviews.author: Kam Williams

reviews.text: Sticking with the same winning formula, Phillips has made a near carbon copy of the original. This makes it less surprising but still entertaining.
reviews.author: Matthew Toomey

reviews.text: There are guffaws of rude comedic shock and there are hair raising incidents, but it still feels like a poor sequel.
reviews.author: Andrew L. Urban

reviews.text: A monkey drug mule, a monk with a vow of silence, trans-sexual, Russian thugs, a kidnapping and a cut off finger are some of the disparate elements of this highly anticipated sequel, which sadly is only a pale imitation of the very funny original
reviews.author: Louise Keller

reviews.text: Its sense of fun-loving camaraderie feels forced and tinged with buzz-killing danger.
reviews.author: John P. McCarthy

reviews.text: Giving the people what they want is one thing. Making nearly the exact same movie a second time, but shifting the setting to Thailand, is just ... what, lazy? Arrogant? Maybe a combination of the two.
reviews.author: Christy Lemire

reviews.text: The stock dismissal "more of the same" has rarely been more accurately applied to a sequel than to The Hangover Part II, which ranks as little more than a faded copy of its predecessor superimposed on a more brightly colored background.
reviews.author: Andrew Barker

reviews.text: What happens in Bangkok isn't as much fun as when it happened in Vegas, but it's still worth the trip.
reviews.author: Michael Rechtshaffen

reviews.text: Darker and meaner than the original but just as funny and horrifying.
reviews.author: Jane Crowther

synopsis: Two years after the disastrous events in Las Vegas, it is now Stu's (Ed Helms) turn to walk down the aisle. Since his bride is from Thailand, Stu decides to hold the wedding there. Desperately hoping to avoid the mayhem of Doug's (Justin Bartha) bachelor party, Stu chooses what he thinks will be a safe option: an alcohol-free, prewedding brunch. But this being Thailand, and with Phil (Bradley Cooper) and Alan (Zach Galifianakis) again in attendance, anything can happen.
